title.value: Graph Anomaly Detection in Time Series: A Survey
title.justification: This clearly states the focus of the paper as a survey on Graph Anomaly Detection in Time Series.
title.quote: Graph Anomaly Detection in Time Series: A Survey

extractions.description: This paper conducts a comprehensive and up-to-date review of methods for Time-Series Anomaly Detection (TSAD) using graphs, referred to as G-TSAD. It introduces new concepts, surveys state-of-the-art techniques, and discusses their strengths and drawbacks. Additionally, it covers datasets and evaluation metrics, and points out current research challenges and future directions.

type.justification: The paper conducts an empirical review of existing techniques and compares them along with datasets, applications, and evaluation metrics.
type.quote: In this survey, we conduct a comprehensive and up-to-date review of TSAD using graphs, referred to as G-TSAD. [...] Finally, we discuss the technical challenges and potential future directions for possible improvements in this research field.

name.justification: The main focus of the paper is on anomaly detection in time-series data.
name.quote: Time-Series Anomaly Detection (TSAD) is an important task in various time-series applications such as e-commerce, cybersecurity, vehicle maintenance, and healthcare monitoring.

name.justification: The paper extensively discusses recent graph-based approaches for TSAD.
name.quote: While many existing TSAD algorithms have effectively handled intra-variable dependencies, capturing inter-variable dependencies remains under-explored in the TSAD field. In recent years, Graph-based Approaches (GA) have become increasingly popular in the machine learning community due to the graphâ€™s ability to represent complex data structures.

name.justification: The secondary focus of the paper is on anomaly detection within graph-structured data.
name.quote: Graph Anomaly Detection (GAD) is an active research field that focuses on detecting abnormalities at various levels within graph-structured data, including individual graph nodes, graph edges, sub-graphs of a graph, and the whole abnormal graphs.
